message: 00:12:23.000 This evening on Conversations from Penn State we’ll be talking with Holley Mignosi and Dorothy Strachan, curators of the recent exhibit “Conversation Pieces…” at the Palmer Museum of Art. Thanks so much for appearing on Conversations from Penn State.

speaker: LLM1
message: 00:12:41.000 Thank you Ron.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:12:42.000 The Palmer Museum of Art here at Penn State is an ideal venue for a conversation. It’s in a renovated Mill structure and the building is surrounded by a beautiful garden.

speaker: LLM1
message: 00:12:56.000 But the building itself is really, is really the conversation piece.

message: 00:13:14.000 That’s the general light shade? Oh that really wasn’t the intention of the exhibit. However what happens is when you do an exhibit of conversation pieces that in fact, lend themselves to talking about - More LLM2: 00:13:27.000 Well as you can tell from our conversation I think the exhibit raised some issues for us regarding conversations so why don’t you give people an idea of what’s it about? LLM1: 00:13:39.000 The exhibit is an international group of works - More LLM2: 00:13:42.000 But by doing so it becomes a conversation piece itself.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:13:44.000 Yeah exactly.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:13:46.000 So uh the exhibit is a world group of works from the 17th through the 21st century that deal with conversations.

speaker: LLM1
message: 00:14:55.000 Conversation pieces can be described as works of art that have characteristics of being autobiographical, more personal, intimate, cozy, political, and revealing human practices.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:15:08.000 That’s a lot of ideas packed into one sentence. You wanna try to unpack that a little bit for me? LLM1: 00:15:15.000 Well conversation pieces are in fact a social genre. Most of the conversations - More LLM2: 00:15:20.000 Part of a genre is that they are broad and they span a lot of Use LLM1: 00:15:24.000 We’re not talking just about written conversations that don’t have to be words.

speaker: LLM1
message: 00:15:29.000 They could be actions could be drawings, facial expressions, gesture they can be all sorts of things.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:15:37.000 Okay I got it, so conversation pieces really is a way for artists to study interactions in society more than the specific thing you’re saying.

speaker: LLM2
message: 00:15:46.000 Okay so let me see if I can characterize it for myself I think what I’m hearing is a widespread We’ll be back with more on Conversations from Penn State - 60 Second Muzak follow LLM: 00:15:56.Yeah, the folks at the Palmer Museum of Art.

LLM1: 00:16:36.000 Since you have talked a lot - more LLM2: 00:16:38.000 If you wish that we do some things this appearance that normally would not be happening I would - more LLM1: 00:16:44.000 This is a conversation piece in itself. It’s between scientists and artists that are dealing with the same subject. Whether or not that conversation follows through for the exhibit, that sort of depends on the people viewing it.

It turns out that the answer to this question has to do with the fact that, unlike fluents, instantaneous states are also individuated by the KL conditioned on. Additionally, we are able to hide this complexity because the bidirectional models avoid the issue of having to separately represent contrasting utterances for the same information state (It also turns out that the original investigation is much more complicated—i.e., a constant ∈ communicates the admissible salience difference, so it is not clear what would become of the quantifier in cases where there is no such difference).

speaker: LLM2
message: 1CJ AND A1JT7 This is a much simplified version of a much more nuanced investigation about the differences between these models, which makes use of Partial Order Sets in both agent situations. These set up a rigorous language—i.e., meaningful world representations so that J could change their assessments, L could now be able to make false utterances conveying the fact that they brought a can of Diet Coke along with the fact that they knew the person was a person, and they knew his goal was to gain a can of Diet Coke, and ultimately, they could infer that he knew tout court. This seems to be the only plausible result given the fact that everyone is always in some state and we let Linguistic Linear Modules stand alone in the absence of contexts established by agents (and a series of understandable, yet complex explananda hinge on this). Moreover, B_member says that a “new interaction between these representations when the content of belief becomes salient” (i.e., the only time that even sets, like the attraction sets in the passive system, seem to have interest; it is a system that accommodates all linguistic dependencies without introducing a necessary compositionality requirement) facilitates the transmission of information:

message: 1: Person 1 walks up to Person 2 and says "hi" 2: Person 2 says to Person 1 "hi" LLM2: 3: Person 1 says to Person 2 "can you help me with this" 4: Person 2 says "sure, what's the problem?" LLM3: 5: Person 1 says "this paragraph of my paper isn't clear to me" 6: Person 2 says "what does it say?" LLM4: 7: Person 1 says “R” 8: Person 2 says "the problem you need to work on is..."

message: 9: Person 1 says" ok, thank you"

speaker: LLM2

speaker: LLM2
message: 13: Person 2 walks away from Person 1 Revision: 14: Person 2 moves off to revise his/her work (telling Person 1) "I'll be over here if you need help again". Person 1 goes back to the activity upon which Person 2 was engaged at 8.

speaker: LLM1
message: 15: Person 1 walks over and says "hi" 16: Person 1 and Person 2 engage in another LLM in the process of doing the Revision activity, or Person 2 moves to read out loud to Person 1 for feedback or self-evaluation.

speaker: LLM2
message: 17: Person 2 says "hi" and goes back to reading aloud.

speaker: LLM1
message: 18: Person 1 listens to Person 2 read aloud and says "I like how you emphasized that sentence" or "I want to make the slide look more like this", or "why do you keep asking him/her to underline".

speaker: LLM2
message: 19: Person 1 says something along the lines of either "Would you show me how to do this?", or "Would your suggest to him/her a specific rephrasing of this introductory/piano verb/use of the word "or", or "is it okay if I point to the slide during the presentation and "action" the toughness of the statements".

speaker: LLM1
message: 20: Person 1 does the thing s/he asked for and then wanders off. Person 2 may or may not continue with Revision, but will at the least

speaker: LLM2

speaker: LLM2

speaker: LLM1
message: 26: Person 1 engages in LLM Experience. Person 2, having resumed revision, engages in self-evaluation, perceiving the previous LLM as a success for that thing. The End.

speaker: LLM2
message: 27: Person 1 engages in LLM Discussion.

speaker: LLM1
message: 28: Person 2 engages in LLM Experience.

speaker: LLM2

speaker: LLM1
message: 30: Person 2 engages in LLM Discussion.

speaker: LLM2
message: 31: Person 1 observes Person 2 engaged in revision and sees that Person 2 with toots and staffs from under the v line do not need to be there, and wanders off, leaving Person 2 to continue Revision.

speaker: LLM1

speaker: LLM1
message: 38: Person 2 wanders off from Person 1, allowing Person 1 to engage in LLM Experience and catch up to Person 2, Reviewing person 2's work.

speaker: LLM1
message: 10 Obtained with the proposal: Hello. (It’s Sunday. Maybe it’s better to prepare meals in the afternoon. The rest of the day is free.) Person2: 12 (as the general principle captured by this utterance.) (In order to be able to communicate, (both speakers have to have) the capacity to produce and understand structures such as “nominative subject-verb-object”). The true underlying goal is no longer (at least, not directly) the production (by Person 1 for the benefit of Person 2) of grammatically adequate sentences, but self-interested linguistic tokens.

speaker: LLM2
message: 22 Grammaticality still exists, but is now a mere secondary byproduct of speaker’s intent.

speaker: LLM1
message: 14 Again, it is a communicator’s competence not a grammar which lends the context-dependent meaning.

speaker: LLM2
message: 25 Intended utterance understanding derives entirely from a competence to produce hairy/fairy (humorous) agreement, tenses in propositional gesture, order, tree structures, thematic roles, aspect. This competence can be called ‘descriptive’. As for rules, they emerge by referential manipulation on descriptivism ‒ if there is a maxim of grownness, it would be (being) mutually intelligible

speaker: LLM1
message: 16 The word ‘competence’ is used deliberately, as compared to ‘grammar’, since the latter might be taken to imply an autonomous entity.

speaker: LLM2
message: 26 Speech acts can be truth-apt although this is not intended directly. To say that person Ur has a competence to utter t is the converse of the competence to comprehend t, although it would mean nothing unless speech acts could be truth-apt. What I have in mind (and which the audience will hopefully find) is coherent. This will have to be fleshed out with regard to reflexive, locative quotative and other kinds of utterances.

speaker: LLM1
message: 18 A precise definition is required; ‘descriptive’ and/or ‘linguistically competent’ are expressions open for interpretation.
